repnme.cdata!:
Yemen - Institutional Development for
            Public Administration, Legal and Judicial Devlopment and
            Public Sector Management Adjustment Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The report covers three projects. The
            Institutional Development for Public Administration Project
            (IDPAP) had the following ratings: highly unsatisfactory
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, negligible institutional
            development impact, unsatisfactory Bank performance, and
            highly unsatisfactory Borrower performance. The Legal and
            Judicial Development Project had the following ratings:
            moderately unsatisfactory outcome, unlikely sustainability,
            modest institutional development impact, unsatisfactory Bank
            performance, and satisfactory Borrower performance. The
            Public Sector Management Adjustment Project had the
            following ratings: moderately unsatisfactory outcome,
            unlikely sustainability, modest institutional development
            impact, moderately satisfactory Bank performance, and
            moderately satisfactory Borrower performance. Experience
            with these projects highlights the following lessons: (a)
            when the project environment changes dramatically, the Bank
            must be ready to restructure key projects in the portfolio;
            (b) the Bank must be more prepared to stay the course in
            critical governance sectors; and (c) reforms need to be
            supported with experienced staff based in the Yemen field office.

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Yemen - Institutional
            Development for a Public Administration Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated unsatisfactory:
            although project restructuring helped to accelerate
            implementation, the leadership of the Ministry of Civil
            Service and Administrative Reform (MCSAR) continued to be
            distracted by the issues of unification, civil strife, and
            national healing. Project sustainability is unlikely. Both
            World Bank and Borrower performances were rated
            unsatisfactory. Despite the fact that the project was
            negatively affected by factors not under the Borrower's
            control and that the project's reform and development
            objectives remian valid, the project produced several
            important lessons: Administrative reform projects require
            close supervision and continuous dialogue and adaptability.
            Staff development and training must be carried out in the
            context of a strategic plan that takes into account both
            institutional needs and the career enhancement of the
            individuals concerned. The capacity for project management
            needs to be assured during the project design phase and
            should be operational at the onset of project
            implementation. Beenficiary institutions need to be involved
            in project implementation. Supervision missions should
            include staff--especially local field office staff--with
            language abilities. Physical assets should be managed and
            properly maintained through a systematic inventory control
            system. Sound financial management and internal controls are
            critical for curbing corruption and fund mismanageement.
            Both internal and external audit functions are needed

18151196.admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa
18151196.theme: Education for the knowledge economy,Other public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
Yemen Arab Republic - Institutional
            Development For Public Administration Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's overall objective is
            to assist the Government in its institution building
            efforts. Specifically, the project will provide the Ministry
            of Civil Service and Administrative Reform (MCSAR) and the
            National Institute of Public Administration (NIPA) with
            technical assistance, training and logistical support to:
            (i) strengthen MCSAR's ability to offer advice in
            governmental organization and operations; personnel policy
            and administration; and manpower and training planning; (ii)
            establish a management information system in MCSAR to
            respond to the manpower and personnel planning needs of the
            Government; (iii) assist MCSAR to assess the consistency of
            its structure and operation with its function and mandates;
            (iv) improve the quality, efficiency and coverage of
            NIPA's education, training and consultancy services;
            and (v) review and redesign NIPA's internal decision
            making structures and course planning procedures.
